Question 2.Explanation: The two legally recognized accounting bodies in Nigeria are: Institute of Chartered Accountant of Nigeria, (ICAN) and Association of National Accountants of Nigeria (ANAN). ICAN was founded 1st, September 1965 and ANAN 1st, January 1979.

Question 6.Question:
Use the information below to answer this question.

Ezekiel Malgwi is a retailer. He recorded sales representing 95% cash and 5% credit. He took the total cash sales of N 19,000 from the business tray and banked it.

The credit sales for the period would be
Question 6.Explanation:
95% of sales = Cash

95% x sales = N 19,000

Sales = N 19,000/95%

Sales = N 19,000/0.95

Sales = N 20,000

Credit sales = 5% of sales

= 5% x N 20,000

= 5/100 x N 20,000

= N 1,000

Question 8.Question: Which accounting concept supports the assertion that economic reality takes precedence over legal issues?
Question 8.Explanation: Substance over form is a concept that takes into consideration of economic reality more than legal issues. It is an accounting principle used "to ensure that financial statements give a complete, relevant, and accurate picture of transactions and events."

Question 22.Question: In a control account, provision for bad debts is found on the
Question 22.Explanation: Provision for bad debts is debited on the credit side of the sales ledger control account. Question 23.Explanation: Closing stocks are only ascertained at the end of the period through stock valuation. There are different methods of stock valuation such as Last-in-first-out (LIFO) and First-in-first-out (FIFO).

Question 24.Question:
During the year ended 31st, December 2001, Nuju Enterprises paid rent as follows:

Jan. 20- 24,000 for a period of 4 months

May 16 - 30,000 for a period of 5 months

Oct. 15 – 36,000 for a period of 6 months

What is the overpaid portion of the rent?
Question 24.Explanation:
Total months paid = 4 + 5 + 6 = 15 months

Excess = 15 – 12 = 3 months

Rent per month from October = N 36,000/6 = N 6,000

Overpaid rent for the year = 3 months x N 6,000

= N 18,000

Question 30.Question: Income and expenditure account is more informative than receipts and payments account because it discloses
Question 30.Explanation: Income and expenditure accounts are based on accrual concept that it takes account of both debtors and creditors unlike receipt and payment account. Question 31.Question: A company has two departments X and Y. Y transferred goods to X at a profit margin of 25%. N10,000 worth of goods was not sold at the end of the accounting period. How much is the unrealized profit?
Question 31.Explanation:
Selling price is N 10,000 and profit margin is 25%

Price at transfer is N (10,000 – 25% of 10,000) = N (10,000 – 8,000)

= N 2,000

Unrealized profit = N 2,000

Question 36.Explanation: Both opening statements and closing statement of affairs are opened to ascertain the opening capital and closing capital respectively. A statement prepared with opening assets and liabilities is known as Opening Statement of Affairs (to ascertain the opening capital). Similarly, a statement prepared with closing assets and liabilities is known as Closing Statement of Affairs (to ascertain the closing capital).

AssetsNLiabilitiesN
Cash70,000Creditors85,000
Inventory58,000Bank Loan60,000

Asset = Capital + Liabilities

N (7,000 + 58,000 + 100,000) = Capital + N (85,000 + 60,000)

228,000 = Capital + 145,000

Capital = N (225,000 - 145,000)

Capital = N 83,000

Question 38.Question: Receipts and payments account is the summary of
Question 38.Explanation: Receipt and payment account is opened in place of cash book. It is a summarized form of Cash Book. It starts with opening Cash and Bank balance (sometimes they are merged) and ends with their closing balances. All receipts are recorded on its left-hand (Debit) side and all payments are recorded on its right-hand (credit) side.

Question 41.Question: For the purpose of conversion of a partnership to a company, a total purchase consideration of N3.6m was paid. If 30% of the purchase consideration was in cash and the rest by 50k shares, how many shares were issued?
Question 41.Explanation:
Cash = 30% of N3.6m

= 30/100 x 3,600,000

= 1,080,000

Shares of 50k = N3,600,000 - N1,080,000 = N 2,520,000 @ 50k per share

Total shares issued = N 2,520,000/ N 0.5

= 5,040,000 shares

Question 49.Explanation: Gross profit in branch adjustment of a/c is credited to P & L a/c.

Options.Value: N 300
N 1,050
N 1,200
N 1,950

Question 50.Question:
Mamsa Nigeria limited issued 20,000 ordinary shares of N1.50 per share on 2nd July 2002. 1,500 ordinary shares were fully subscribed for and their monies received as below:

.₦
On application 0.40
On allotment 0.20
First call (including premium of ₦0.50)0.70

The last and final call was yet to be made.

What is the balance of the ordinary share capital account after the first call was received?
Question 50.Explanation:
Application = 0.40 x 1,500 = N 600

Allotment = 0.20 x 1,500 = N 300

First call = 0.70 x 1.500 = N 1,050

Total = N1,950
